questions.clue: In 1440, Johannes Gutenberg invented this device, revolutionizing the way books were produced.
In 1775, this Scotsman improved the steam engine, greatly enhancing industrial efficiency.
In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell was awarded the first patent for this communication device.
In 1903, these brothers achieved powered flight with their aircraft, the Wright Flyer.
In 1947, the first point-contact transistor was developed at Bell Labs, marking the start of this technological era.
This detective, known for his logical reasoning and violin playing, was created by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.
Created by J.K. Rowling, this young wizard attends Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
This giant whale is pursued by Captain Ahab in the novel by Herman Melville.
In 'The Great Gatsby', this mysterious millionaire, created by F. Scott Fitzgerald, throws lavish parties.
This character, created by Fyodor Dostoevsky, struggles with guilt and redemption after committing a murder in 'Crime and Punishment'.
This Italian dish is traditionally made with long thin noodles and a sauce of tomatoes, garlic, and olive oil.
This Mexican dish consists of a folded tortilla filled with cheese and often meat, then grilled or fried.
Originating in Japan, this dish involves raw fish or other seafood over vinegared rice.
A staple of Indian cuisine, this bread is typically baked in a tandoor oven and served with curries.
This French stew, named after its cooking vessel, features a mix of meats, vegetables, and herbs cooked slowly.
This force keeps your feet on the ground and prevents you from floating into space.
This phenomenon causes a straw to appear bent when placed in a glass of water.
When you rub your hands together to warm them up, you are converting kinetic energy into this type of energy.
This principle explains why a bicycle remains upright while moving but not when stationary.
This principle describes how an increase in the speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in pressure or potential energy.
In 1911, this famous painting by Leonardo da Vinci was stolen from the Louvre by an Italian handyman.
In 1990, two men dressed as police officers stole 13 pieces of art from this Boston museum, in a heist valued at $500 million.
This Dutch artist's painting 'The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen' was stolen in 2020 from the Singer Laren museum.
In 2004, Edvard Munch's famous painting 'The Scream' was stolen from this Oslo museum during daylight.
In 2003, thieves stole paintings worth $30 million, including works by Picasso and Van Gogh, from this Manchester museum.

final.clue: In 1981, this company released the first personal computer to use the MS-DOS operating system, setting a standard for future PCs.
